item.title: OBSERVATIONS ON REVELATION
item.description:
OBSERVATIONS ON REVELATION

I. Literary Form

A. Large number of doxological passages: 1:5-6; 4:8, 11; 5:9-10, 12, 13; 7:10, 12;

11:15, 17-18; 12:10-12; 15:3-4; 19:1-2, 5, 6-8

B. Simple vocabulary

C. Numerological interest

  1. Threes: three measures of barley (6:6); three woes of three angels (8:13) = three plagues? (9:18); three unclean spirits (16:13); three gates on each side of the new Jerusalem (21:13); a third of the trees, sea, creatures, ships (8:8-9); a third of the rivers (8:10-11); a third of the sun, moon, stars not shining for a third of the day (8:12); a third of men (9:15); a third of the stars (12:4)

item.title: THE SEVEN CHURCHES OF ASIA
item.description:
THE SEVEN CHURCHES OF ASIA

I. Literary Analysis

A. Length: the letters are approximately the same.

B. Unity with chapter 1

  1. 2:1b = 1:16 holds the seven stars in his right hand

1:12b-13a walks in the midst of the seven golden candlesticks

  1. 2:8b = 1:17b the first and the last

1:18a who was dead and lives again

  1. 2:12b = 1:16b the sword of my mouth (out of his mouth came a sharp two-

edged sword)

item.title: THE SEVEN DAYS OF CONSUMMATION
item.description:
THE SEVEN DAYS OF CONSUMMATION

Part I: Recurring Elements

Recurring elements give clues to the common identity of elements that appear separately in the Book of Revelation.

I. Earthquake (seven references)

A. Passages

  1. 6:12 (seal 6)

a. The sun became as black as burlap made out of hair.

b. The whole moon became blood.

c. The stars in the sky fell to the earth.

d. The sky was removed.

e. Every mountain and island moved out of their place.

item.title: REVELATION: GOOD AND EVIL IN ETERNAL PERSPECTIVE
item.description:
REVELATION: GOOD AND EVIL IN ETERNAL PERSPECTIVE

Good triumphs over evil.

Good and evil are not equal opposites in power or legitimacy.

Good and evil are not equally eternal. Evil has a beginning and an end.

Evil is allowed.

Evil does not simply take over and “bully” people around undeterred.

Evil is temporary (limited in length).

In comparison to good, individual evils are short-lived along the way.

Death removes it from the scene.
